action.action-desc: Mr. Blumenauer introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committees on Transportation and Infrastructure and Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To establish a Road Usage Fee Pilot Program to study mileage-based fee systems, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Road Usage Fee Pilot Program Act of 2013 .

paragraph.text: The 2009 report of the National Surface Transportation Infrastructure Financing Commission recommends a transition away from the fuel tax to a more stable funding source, noting that a mileage-based fee system is the consensus choice for policy leaders.

The 2008 report of the National Surface Transportation and Revenue Study Commission recommends further study of the implementation of mileage-based fee systems at the State level and of their compatibility with a national revenue system, noting that in the long run, a mileage-based fee system seems the most likely and appropriate method to be implemented.

According to the Congressional Budget Office, the revenue raised from the gas tax since its last increase in 1992 has lost over one-third of its purchasing power due to increasing fuel efficiency, changing transportation patterns, and inflation.
By 2030, the corporate average fuel economy standards will have reduced Highway Trust Fund receipts by more than 20 percent.
The fuel tax revenue mechanism results in some industries paying more than their commensurate road use.
Since 1990, while gas tax revenues have consistently decreased, the number of vehicle miles traveled nationally has consistently increased.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Treasury (in this Act referred to as the Secretary) shall establish a competitive grant program to be known as the Road Usage Fee Pilot Program (in this Act referred to as the Program) to make grants to eligible entities toâ€”

paragraph.text: conduct pilot studies of methods for recording and reporting the number of miles traveled by particular vehicles;
conduct pilot studies of payment, enforcement, and privacy protection methods for mileage-based fee systems; and
implement mileage-based fee systems in jurisdictions that have adopted a plan for such systems.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a grant under the Program, an eligible entity shall submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such form, and containing such information and assurances as the Secretary may require.
In awarding grants under the Program, the Secretary shall select pilot studies that, in combination, explore means to address the following concerns:

paragraph.text: Protection of personal privacy.
Ease of public compliance.
Level of public acceptance.
Geographic and income equity.
Integration with State and local transportation revenue mechanisms.
Administrative issues.
Cost.
Enforcement issues.
Potential for fraud or evasion.
Feasibility of implementation.

subsection.text: In awarding grants under the Program, the Secretary shall give priority to pilot studies thatâ€”

paragraph.text: serve as a model for broad implementation of a mileage-based fee system;
address concerns of rural and urban user equity;
involve multistate projects;
have a high volume of enrolled vehicles;
integrate with State and local revenue systems;
integrate with local demand management plans;
are likely to lead to implementation of mileage-based fee systems, dependent on the results of the program;
integrate with other intelligent transportation system technologies; and
test the proposed revenue collection system by collecting and distributing revenue.

subsection.header: Required minimum funds for planning organizations
subsection.text: In awarding grants under the Program, the Secretary shall ensure that not less than 10 percent of funds available under the Program in a fiscal year are reserved for pilot studies carried out in conjunction with metropolitan planning organizations or regional transportation planning organizations.

An eligible entity that receives a grant under this Act shall provide funds, from non-Federal sources, in an amount equal to 20 percent of the amount of grant funds provided to the entity to carry out the activities supported by the grant.
The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, shall establish the following working groups:

paragraph.text: A technology and privacy working group that shallâ€”

subparagraph.text: evaluate the technology platforms and standards used in the Program;
develop national technology standards and make recommendations to provide consistency in transportation data laws; and
balance the effectiveness of revenue systems with user privacy.

paragraph.text: A transportation system and equity working group that shall evaluate the costs of collection and administration of methods studied in the Program and the success of such methods in achieving rural and urban user equity.
An environmental working group that shall evaluate the potential of the methods studied in the Program to manage demand and to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases.

subsection.text: Each of the working groups established under subsection (a) shall be comprised of at least 1 member with relevant subject-matter experience in the private sector and at least 1 member with relevant subject-matter experience in the public sector.

Not later than 2 years after the date of the first disbursement of funds under a grant under the Program, the Secretary shall submit to Congress an interim report describing the progress of the Program, the progress of the working groups established under section 4(a), and any data or results from the Program.

Not later than 4 years after the date of the first disbursement of funds under a grant under the Program, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a final report containing data and results from the Program, an analysis of the feasibility of each method studied to be used as a mileage-based fee system, and the evaluations done by the working groups established under section 4(a).

paragraph.text: The term eligible entity means one or more of the following:

subparagraph.text: A State government or political subdivision thereof.
A local government or political subdivision thereof.

paragraph.text: The term metropolitan planning organization has the meaning given that term in section 134(b) of title 23, United States Code.
The term regional transportation planning organization has the meaning given that term in section 134(b) of title 23, United States Code.
